posts.name:
Laura Bolton
Laura Bolton
posts.content:
I have too much content to post 

I can get 10 or more ‚Äúdownloads‚Äù or ‚Äúinspirations‚Äù in a row, especially if Im in nature and being super present. So I jot them down in my notes app.

I call them downloads because it feels like its something flowing through me rather than something Im consciously thinking up myself.

I often read my notes back and think ‚Äúdid I write that?!‚Äù

Inspiration / ideas come to me from every conversation I have and at least one thing happens to me in my life every day that I could post about or turn into a podcast episode

And quite frankly it freaks me out, overwhelms me, and sometimes causes paralysis

Does this happen to anyone else?!

If so how do you manage it?!

Im concerned I may have a disorder 

P.S Thank God for the notes app 

P.P.S It‚Äôs gone up to 406 since I took this screen shot yesterday

comments.commentText:
I do something similar. Here's my little "system.'
I'm constantly writing ideas in the Reminders app in my iphone.
Once a week, I block out "content creation time" where I will take those ideas and put them into Notion -- where I organize my content ideas.
Whatever the idea is (sometimes it's just a headline, sometimes it's a full story) I'll blab it all into ChatGPT and then use it to help me turn it into a post. With some sort of actionable takeaway for readers.
Kelsey Schaefer sounds like more work than Im willing to do  And I refuse to use ChatGPT ever. But if it works for you, awesome Ô∏è
I have an infinite number of random notes. I‚Äôm impressed that you organized them into a folder
Michael Kainatsky but what does one do when they get 12 ideas in the space of 10 mins?!
Michael Kainatsky ‚Äî maybe I should try that too! I like living in the edge :)

posts.commentAdded: Its amazing how inspiration flows in nature! Finding balance can be tough‚Äîtry setting aside time to reflect on your ideas. You got this! üåø‚ú®

posts.name:
Chuck Herrin, CISSP, CCSP, NACD.DC
Chuck Herrin, CISSP, CCSP, NACD.DC
posts.content:
The measure of morale isn‚Äôt net promoter score or how many pizza parties you throw, it‚Äôs how your employees feel on Sunday evening. 

Companies who value flexibility and invest in their people will continue to win. I‚Äôm jazzed every Sunday because I believe in our mission and have an executive team that demonstrates that they trust their folks.

It‚Äôs not complicated. You running a business, or a daycare?
posts.commentAdded: Absolutely! Employee morale stems from genuine trust and support. Excited to see more companies embracing this approach for lasting success!

Sumit Mishra

posts.name:
Cory Bray
Cory Bray
posts.content: Instead of being like Google and giving your product team one day a week to work on whatever they want‚Ä¶how about having the product team work one day a week on things the sales team thinks will close deals but isn‚Äôt otherwise high on the product backlog?

comments.commentText: The point of those exercises is to instill innovation and creativity. What you‚Äôre suggesting would be the equivalent of telling salespeople that instead of time for self development and skill up you want them to work on updating the crm because marketing has campaigns that could be more effective if they did

Andrew Dodds which is exactly what every company does and it works when they do it. 

Innovation comes from customers. Salespeople are the conduit to that. Learning the latest JavaScript framework is for the eng resume‚Ä¶not for the customer.
Andrew Dodds thats exactly what every team does and it costs salespeople their jobs if they don't.

Bootstrapped startups naturally do this, because revenue is oxygen. The products are usually much simpler to use, and solve the problem better.

VC backed companies can ship whatever they want because they have the cash to do it. Some will land, some won't. Listening to customer feedback is low on the priority list unless growth is slow and churn is high. Then they try to play 24 months of catch-up in two quarters and realize they can't because of all the bloat and tech debt they have.

posts.commentAdded: Great perspective! Collaborating more closely with sales can drive innovation and directly impact closing deals. A win-win approach!

posts.name:
Business Development - The Missing Link Between Marketing & Sales - 540,000 Members Strong
Business Development - The Missing Link Between Marketing & Sales - 540,000 Members Strong
posts.content:
‚ÄúLOVE BEATS POWER: A RADICAL WORKPLACE SHAKE-UP!‚Äù
Did you know that 70% of employees feel undervalued at work? About 85% feel disconnected from their colleagues and employers. We're living in a culture of power obsession, and it's killing our workplaces.

This is about us, our colleagues, our bosses, and our businesses. It's about how we've been prioritizing personal gain and power over love and connection. And let me tell you, it's not working!

What if we flipped the script? What if we put love and connection first?

Research shows that workplaces prioritizing connection and empathy see a 50% reduction in staff turnover. Plus, an increase in productivity by 20%. That's huge!

Here are some ways to bring love and connection into your workplace:

- Start with empathy: Understand your colleagues' perspectives. Listen to their concerns.

- Encourage collaboration: Foster a sense of teamwork. Make everyone feel included.

- Promote open communication: Encourage honest feedback. Be transparent with your employees.

- Recognize efforts: Celebrate small wins. Show appreciation.

Do you think love can really beat power in the corporate world?

Repost Ô∏è if you find it useful. Follow me,andfor more insights like these!

Lead differently! Beat yesterday! Be better humans.
posts.commentAdded: Absolutely! Prioritizing empathy and connection can transform workplace culture. Lets lead with love for a more engaged and productive team! ‚ù§Ô∏è #WorkplaceWellness

Sourish Bujarbaruah üìå
Sourish Bujarbaruah üìå
posts.content:
ùêÑùê±ùêöùêúùê≠ùê•ùê≤, ùê≠ùê°ùêûùê´ùêû'ùê¨ ùêßùê® ùê©ùê®ùê¢ùêßùê≠ ùê¢ùêß ùêûùê±ùê©ùê•ùêöùê¢ùêßùê¢ùêßùê† ùê≤ùê®ùêÆùê´ùê¨ùêûùê•ùêü ùê≠ùê® ùê®ùê≠ùê°ùêûùê´ùê¨. ùêìùê® ùêØùêöùê•ùê¢ùêùùêöùê≠ùêû ùê≤ùê®ùêÆùê´ùê¨ùêûùê•ùêü ùê¢ùê¨ ùê≠ùê°ùêû ùêßùêûùêûùêù ùê®ùêü ùê≠ùê°ùêû ùê°ùê®ùêÆùê´. 

No, you don't have to explain yourself to everyone.

Caring about what others will think is the biggest barrier in our lives.

It's perfectly okay to keep some things "private".

The people who understand and really love you, will remain there. & some people can never be satisfied.

We all should learn to validate ourselves at first. It's important.

What if I ask you, list me a few reasons why you should feel good about yourself? The answers:
- You've improved a lot. Compare yourself now to how you were.
- You know you're not perfect. Yet you wish to become better.
- You've unique skills that not many people have. This is your power.

 How do you validate yourself?
- Notice how you feel & what you need. Eg, I feel angry, I need time.
- Talk nicely to yourself, always.
- Refrain from self-pity talks.
- Don't be hateful towards yourself.

Ô∏èAn instant exercise that works:
------------------
Imagine you want to get validated my someone.
No, you're not getting validated.
It's making you anxious. 
THE TRICK: " What would I like this person to say?"
Then say that thing 10 times to yourself.

I always believe: Expand your circle wisely. Learn to be happy with you.

"Bees don't waste time explaining to flies why honey is better" .

My name isand I am into HR, Recruitments, Innovation & Psychology.
Share me your stories to connect.

comments.commentText: Was preparing my notes as a key speaker for a seminar scheduled on January 22, 2025 when I thought to share this in LinkedIn.

posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Self-validation is key to personal growth. Lets focus on nurturing our unique strengths and uplifting each other! üí™‚ú®

posts.name:
Ashton Harvey
Ashton Harvey
posts.content:
Great reminder Ian Koniak. ADHD is often misunderstood and goes undiagnosed, and I suspect I may have it too.

Back when I was a seller, time management was a huge struggle for me. I‚Äôd tell my manager:

1. "I‚Äôm busy all day but not accomplishing much."

2. "I get too distracted and can‚Äôt focus."

3. "I have too much on my plate and feel overwhelmed."

4. "I know prospecting is important, but I don‚Äôt prioritize it."

5. "I can‚Äôt figure out what to tackle first."

6. "I waste so much time during the day."

Does any of this sound familiar?

Traditional "time management" advice didn‚Äôt work for me. What did work was setting intentions. I‚Äôd choose 3-5 key goals for the day‚Äîlike prospecting or emailing‚Äîwithout being overly specific (e.g., "email prospects" instead of "email John"). I also started segmenting my week:

Certain days are strictly for meetings (internal, customer, or prospect-related).

Other days are dedicated to revenue-generating activities like prospecting.

This shift helped me stay focused, avoid burnout, and align my priorities with my goals. While sales leadership often focuses on daily activity, I‚Äôve found it more productive to track weekly goals.

What strategies have worked for you when it comes to staying productive and focused?

comments.commentText: Ashton Harvey, segmenting work days and setting clear intentions can transform productivity challenges into manageable steps. have you tried time blocking?

posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Setting clear intentions can truly transform productivity. I‚Äôd love to hear more about your weekly goal strategies!

posts.name:
Yash Kumar
Yash Kumar
posts.content:
100 CONVERSATIONS. 0 CONVERSIONS. Been there?

Let's fix it: 

1Ô∏è‚É£ Listen Actively:

‚Üí 46% of buyers rate active listening, as the top skill in sales.

‚Ü≥ Listening ‚Üí Discovering pain points.

‚Ü≥ Pain points ‚Üí Personalized solutions.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Personalize Solutions:

‚Üí 77% of B2B buyers won‚Äôt purchase without a tailored solution.

‚Ü≥ Personalised solutions ‚Üí Questions from prospects.

‚Ü≥ Questions ‚Üí Objections.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Handle Objections Strategically:

‚Üí Top sales reps ask clarifying questions, 54.3% of the time when facing objections.

Objections aren‚Äôt walls‚Äîthey‚Äôre opportunities.

By asking the right questions:

‚Ü≥ You shift focus from price ‚Üí value.

‚Ü≥ You help them arrive at the solution themselves.

‚Ü≥ You build trust while uncovering pain points.

For me, "Trust > Transactions". Always.

Follow to get smarter at "Mindset ‚Üí Money".

Because, you deserve to be in the "1% Club"! Ô∏è

PS: Are you able to add to the list? Share in the comments!

comments.commentText:
Pro Tip: Be Mindful. 

Observe your prospect. Look out for non verbal cues. 

That has been the best trick for me, to tailor the response accordingly.

Sales isn‚Äôt about pushing. 

It‚Äôs about listening, personalizing, and handling objections like a pro.

Shift the focus: pain points ‚Üí solutions ‚Üí trust.

Trust > Transactions.

posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Active listening and personalized solutions are game-changers. Excited to see what others will add! #SalesTips
